title: Tesla shares soar after posting surprise profit
text:
Tesla took investors by surprise Wednesday (October 23) when it delivered - a profit.

The electric car maker has a poor track record when it comes to meeting its own targets.

But it breezed past those troubles in the third quarter by cutting costs and delivering a record number of cars.

The news sent shares soaring 21% in after-hours trading.

All this is a triumph for the man who started the company.

Chief Executive Elon Musk had to step down as chairman after a series of scandals and doubts over his ability to steer the company.

But on Wednesday (October 23), Musk wowed investors.

He said trial production of the Model 3 at Tesla's new Shanghai factory was ahead of schedule.

And he promised to roll out a cheaper SUV - the Model Y next year - along with more self-driving technology.

Musk also said the company was in the final stages of picking a place for a new factory in Europe.

Meaning the company could soon have more capacity to make cars.

Despite Wednesday's good news -- Tesla has yet to prove it can stay in the black.

Some analysts warn the company's breakneck expansion will make it hard to keep costs under control.

Tesla has a whole range of projects lined up from a self-driving semi truck to a new generation of the Tesla Roadster.
description:
Tesla took investors by surprise Wednesday (October 23) when it delivered - a profit. 
              The electric car maker has a poor track record when it comes to meeting its own targets. 
              But it breezed past those troubles in the third quarter by cutting costs and delivering a record number of cars. 
              The news sent shares soaring 21% in after-hours trading. 
              All this is a triumph for the man who started the company. 
              Chief Executive Elon Musk had to step down as chairman after a series of scandals and doubts over his ability to steer the company. 
              But on Wednesday (October 23), Musk wowed investors. 
              He said trial production of the Model 3 at Tesla's new Shanghai factory was ahead of schedule. 
              And he promised to roll out a cheaper SUV - the Model Y next year - along with more self-driving technology. 
              Musk also said the company was in the final stages of picking a place for a new factory in Europe. 
              Meaning the company could soon have more capacity to make cars. 
              Despite Wednesday's good news -- Tesla has yet to prove it can stay in the black. 
              Some analysts warn the company's breakneck expansion will make it hard to keep costs under control. 
              Tesla has a whole range of projects lined up from a self-driving semi truck to a new generation of the Tesla Roadster.
